If you played the last tomb raider game, you will immediately feel right at home with Rise of the Tomb Raider. I say that as a positive thing, becuase Tomb Raider has really improved upon the gameplay elements, graphics and exploration.  So last game was sort of an experiment. It was a reborn of the series and it was a pretty nice, but casual and linear sort of game. This game is still very casual, just like the last game, but levels are more open, and there's things to find in every corner. I like that, becuase im the explorer type in this sort of games. I like exploring to learn more about the world, get upgrades and just get more out of the game.  The story is interesting and kept me playing. I remember that I liked the last tomb raider story as well. This is more of the same. Another journey, but with different landscape. The mountains filled with snow and ice looks great.  Game runs well, but it's really demanding with lots of settings. To play this on ultra you need a beast PC. I play with 980 SLI and because I play 1440p I had to crank some settings down to maintain over 60 fps. This game is filled with all kinds of graphics options, like hair physics, which is only something certain AAA-developers include in their title.  Voiceacting is good, and the sound effect are cool. There's some QTE's in this game, which I don't particulary like. Still, I think the last game had more of it, and most combat in this game is full of action and choice. You can stealth through or go guns blazing. You can also upgrade weapons and equipment more then last game and use that to make the combat more varied.  I honestly don't have any real complaints about this game. It's a good AAA-game with a lenghty story (I probably rush through large parts of it, and also played on an easy difficult mode), nice graphics, story, sound, controls, options menu. Levels are more open, crafing, weapons, etc, have more customization then the last Tomb Raider game.  The ending is very open and definitely sequel baiting. Don't get me wrong though, you get a complete story in this game, but at the same time it does hint at more. I would be okay with another game though. I enjoyed the first remaster of Tomb Raider, and I also enjoyed this title a great deal. Recommended.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is a brilliant additon to the Tomb Raider series. Playing as a grittier, more efficient adventurer gives the player a whole new perspective on Lara Croft. With better puzzles, more interesting and interactive combat and a highly engaging story, Rise of the Tomb Raider makes for an amazing successor to Tomb Raider 2013. Adding much better stealth mechanics to the game provides the player with a whole new way to play the game. However, the game has a particularly short main story. Overall, Rise of the Tomb Raider is a superb addition to the already fantastic Tomb Raider game series.

First off, I recommend the game in principle. It is a good game with a good story.   Story   The Rise of the Tomb Raider continues after the previous Tomb Raider game. The difference now is that, where the previous game (TR) develops Lara as an adventurer, this game (TRofTR) assumes that Lara is already established and therefore there is no character development. The most complex character, in my mind, was the main antagonist. The story itself is generally generic. A secret society tries to find an artefact that will help them take over the world and Lara must stop them.  Spoiler: she does.   Gameplay   As before there are open areas in which you can explore, with faster paced action sequences in between. I enjoyed the open spaces, foraging for supplies, crafting, upgrading my weapons and skills. I must admit though, that I wanted some more action sequences. Death is also not as cringe worthy. You fall off things a fair amount and presumably die, but there isn’t that same sense of being truly scared and being forced to survive as in TR. Yes, I know she grew, but I missed that same urgency that drove you on and on (or something similar to that effect).   Conclusion   It is difficult for me to review TRotTR without having TR in the back of my head. On a technical level TRotTR is far better. Larger environments, more tools and weapons, more options. Better graphics. But story-wise the previous one was better. Lara is just an effective and capable killing machine. The enemies are almost, to a man, all masked, so dehumanised. The main antagonist, however, was painted well and had my empathy.    Open questions to the developers:     Please lose Jonah. He’s annoying and, while I suppose he is required to ground Lara, he did nothing in either games. At least give him his mow hawk back so that he may look bad ♥♥♥ if not act it. Otherwise, if she must have someone to support her, introduce new characters more to the like of Conrad Roth or Angus Grimaldi.   Revaluate whether an “archaeologist” (adventurous or otherwise) would use an actual 1000-year-old authentic trebuchet to destroy the gates of a 1000-year-old city in order to get inside (amongst other autrocities). The amount of destruction of a so far hidden and unknown culture was truly horrific to experience. Puzzles are all well and good, but what’s the point if there is nothing left of the culture to document afterwards?

I've played all the Tomb Raiders since the original on PS1 way back when I was a kid. So as a TR game I really enjoyed this game a lot! It has the feel and the exploration and platforming of a TR game that I love.  The graphics are spectacular with great effects and immersive beautiful environments everywhere! Its really very very well done visually.  What I didn't like though is the difficulty of the game. I played it on the hardest difficulty and it was far to easy! Compared to the last game the combat was just a cakewalk. In fact it was so easy to headsshot every enemy that I NEVER even saw the close combat dodge/quick kill mechanic till the VERY END OF THE GAME when the final boss fight forced you into it as part of the battle. Because of this I had no idea wtf to do LOL like seriously I had no idea wtf was going on since I never saw that screen the ENTIRE game due to the enemies being so easy to headshot with the bow. Even when the enemies get armor and helmets its still a cakewalk.  I remember when they introduced the harder enemies/mercenaries. They play a small clip where they walk out and look all badass.....2 poison arrows later they are dead.... I seriously thought I was being trolled it was so easy.  You will not run out of ammo unless you try to waste it and run out.  Now Im not saying combat isn't fun, cause it is fun...but It just isn't satisfying when you see a room setup for you to use all these perches and such to take out enemies but there is no point in doing all that when you can end a fight in 5 seconds against 10-20 enemies so easily.   The previous games combat was MUCH more satisfying and felt like you earned every victory in battle. People complained so much about the combat that the devs dumbed it down tremendously in this new game. To me I would rather just play a game without the combat if its going to be this easy...just Saying.  Either make a TR game with proper combat or just make a TR game without it entirely next time.   Overall the game is WORTH playing 100%. Just be prepared for easy peezy fights if you are the least bit skilled at shooting games at all!  Also I didn't bother with the endurance or survival modes or whatever they are called. To me that stuff is just hamfisted attempts at making the microtransaction valid.

After the impressive revival of the Tomb Raider franchise in 2013, I had high hopes for this installment. It certainly doesn't disappoint. Rise of the Tomb Raider improves in most, if not all, of the areas that players wanted improvement from Tomb Raider (2013) including more actual tombs! I'll get to that in a bit.   PROS   - Beautiful environments. Graphics were really good generally.  - Voice acting was good, It definitely helps the game.   - The story, overall, is immersive and enjoyable.   - Side quests are a welcome addition that add a bit more length to the game and include some interesting rewards  - Tombs are definitely improved on the 2013 version, there are more of them and they're suitably challenging.   - Character progession offers choice to players. 3 different skill trees with a wide variety of skills that will help personalise your playing experience and augment your play style.   - Plenty of collectibles for people like myself who like that kind of thing. It provides a great reason to explore more of the world as well, which is well worth doing. It's not open world, but it's still fairly expansive in some areas.  - Level design, especially toward the latter stages, is very impressive.    NEUTRAL    - I personally found key bindings on keyboard to be a little awkward, you'll probably want to rebind them.   - The story, although really enjoyable overall, gets a bit cliche toward the end and I found myself beginning to pick holes in it, which ruined the immersion somewhat.    CONS    - Enemy AI just isn't that bright at times.  - Controls when playing with a mouse and keyboard seem a little clumsy. Sometimes you'll randomly miss zip wires and jumps for no reason. I feel like this is a product of the game being exclusive to Xbox initially.  - Definitely some bugs around. I found one type of craftable explosive to be paticularly buggy. As one example, n the final boss battle, it exploded next to the boss, who then just disappeared through the floor meaning I had to reload.

For me this is probably contender for GOTY.   If you loved the previous Tomb Raider reboot, you will most likely love this even more. Personally, I think Crystal Dynamics has somehow pulled off improving on basically every facet of the game in this sequel.  I have seen some people commenting that they think the writting/story is worse in the sequel. I guess you could say that the story is somewhat similar, but yes this is a sequel in a franchise, can you really complain that it has Lara raiding Tombs and there is some crazy fanatical maniacs trying to kill you? If you are looking for a drastically different story, you are looking for another game series...  In terms of gameplay, I don't want to spoil it, but they have added a few game mechanics that do improve the gameplay loop further. While the previous game was about Lara's birth as the character, this one really makes you feel like the full blown Tomb Raider. I don't know why Uncharted 4 is so well regarded, I guess it does have pretty great story and visuals (for PS4), but in my opinion it just cannot compete with RoTR on gameplay. Paritcularly I have always found shooting in Uncharted to be unfuriating garbage (maybe its just having to aim with joysticks), but RoTR combat just feels more dynamic and actually makes me feel like a ruthless killer rather than a clumsy (wisecracking) idiot. Also, as I progress through the game, I keep finding new mechanics that are similar to the new ones in Uncharted 4, but almost always I find that Crystal Dynamics have pulled off something that is more fun/engaging. Even climbing I would say is more fun here, which I have always found to be a mandatory chore in Uncharted. But this is all probably pretty subjective.  In terms of graphics, I am playing this on 4K on Ultra with a gtx 1080 at about 40 fps. The game looks simply amazing, probably the only thing I have seen it rival is Crysis 3. When I moved to 4K, I felt like a lot of games just simply did not hold up, because the greater resolution just made the lack of detail just more evident. RoTR definately holds up, and there are many times where I just stop dead in my tracks and admire the view.  Is this game worth full price: heck yes. It makes me sad how entitled gamers have grown with the quality and amount of content they get for $60. This game has several dozen hours of content, some of the most advanced graphics and tech, a detailed story with engaging gameplay and cost >$100m to make. And if you are looking for this type of experience, Uncharted 4 is really the only other contender. When you look at it that way, how can you argue that the game is worth less than a t-shirt or a ticket to a 2 hour movie...

MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS/READ AT YOUR OWN RISK  Since I finished the game (100% minus DLC and currently exploring the expedition modes), I still feel secure in recommending it to both longtime fans and newcomers. It's a good game in its own way for people who don't know or aren't as knowledgeable of Lara Croft's journey in the game industry, but imo it's not quite what it could be for diehard fans. Don't get me wrong, I very much enjoyed ROTR more than the reboot; it's just still lacking in certain areas that - based on the improvement thus far - I'm mostly confident they'll, well, fix for a lack of better words.  For starters, they captured the sense of adventure better than the reboot by providing better incentives to explore the land as well as expanding said area. Aside from collecting resources, collectibles (ugh), and challenges (double ugh), there's the bonus of a group of people you can interact with who give you missions to carry out. This, on top of the newly designed challenge tombs, makes the world feel more alive through the past and the present. It definitely helps that the entire game is more colorful and vivid than the dull colored maps of the reboot.  As for the action, they added a few more mechanics to spice up the combat a bit. There's an array of weapons to choose from rather than one weapon that's either swapped for a better one or upgraded to look different, and most of the weapons now have specially crafted ammo. In addition to this, they've added on the move crafting to allow different approaches to combat encounters; you can now craft throwables to either damage or distract, both of which can also be upgraded to do more damage or add damage respectively. There are more skills as well, but quite a few of them were hit or miss for me. All this combined with an enhanced survival instinct that allows you to see when an enemy is in view of another gives way for better stealth tactics if that tickles your fancy. I mostly played the game in this manner on the seasoned raider difficulty, so I don't know if that affects my opinion differently, but I'm almost tempted to say that the game seems to push for stealth more than guns blazing - which brings me to my next point.  The game unfortunately still went with the endless amount of men trying to kill one female, and I'll never understand why. This isn't a SJW or feminist point, this is from the standpoint of a longtime fan who wishes to see more adventure and puzzle solving than an illogical one woman army. It literally kills me inside when even the game acknowledges this with its 'oh so witty' comments from said men who can't believe they're getting their asses kicked by Lara Croft. Yes, Lara Croft is a badass but she's a badass because of her intellect more than her ability to kill someone or something. In all the TR games she has killed to survive, but this just feels so forced.  That being said, the puzzles could use more difficulty still. I remember reading an article about how the devs were going to bring back nested puzzles, which they did for the most part, but then they turned around and said they didn't want to make them but so difficult that it would turn players away. I could understand that mentality back when Tomb Raider was first established because players still relied on physical guides or perseverance to get by, but in today's world where in less than a minute you can google the solution if you get stuck, I will never buy that as an excuse to not make your players think. I think there was only one puzzle that took me a second to figure out, and that was only because I got confused about one of the objects and how it was used. I also wish the puzzles existed outside of the challenge tombs.  Quick note about said tombs, I can't express enough how much better they are visually. They're just grand and take the appearance of settings from the likes of Tomb Raider I-III with today's graphics. Though they could use some diversity of the physical secret discovered, they did a superb job nevertheless. The rewards gained are actually worth the raid even if the tombs are still optional.  Last but certainly not least - the plot. It was certainly more compelling than the reboot in that the main enemy is more than a title; there's a backstory, there's emotion, there's a reason why that unfolds and intertwines with Lara's story. I can't say anything was truly shocking, but at least it's not Mathias...a potato is better than Mathias as an enemy. If it wasn't for my need to explore everything, the game would probably be short, so I guess that's a bit of a problem. I long for the days of, as another reviewer put it, globetrotting; I'm pretty sure if there were multiple countries with these kinds of maps the game would be much longer and have more depth but it doesn't seem Crystal Dynamics wants to put that kind of effort into it. The fact that they pretty much recycled the supernatural enemies (yay more undead men /s) and the final climb from the reboot speaks volumes of what kind of effort they put into the plot. I've seen some minor complaints about the overarching enemy, but since I grew up with Natla constantly having a vendetta against Lara it doesn't bother me as long as it's planned out well.  Performance wise, the game worked fine for me. My recent boot up of the game, during a loading screen, it crashed for the first time. There's a few moments where my fps will drop from the 60's-50's to the 30's and one time even 15 fps, other than that the game ran smooth. I have a gtx 780, a locked i5, and 16gb of ram so most of my settings were set to high/very high, and I refused to compromise on the pure hair at least being on because it looked weird off.  As I said, overall it's a good game. There's still room for improvement but it's already quite the upgrade over the reboot. Buy it when you can!  P.S: What happened to Croatia? After throughoutly enjoying the previous reboot Tomb Raider (2013) I was really looking forward to Rise of the Tomb Raider for quite a while now - And it was well worth the wait!  Crystal Dynamics stepped up their game in the graphics department. The game looks absolutely stunning, especially in the cutscenes but also while normal gameplay. Thanks to motion capturing, insanely high end models and highres textures the characters look very lifelike and feel beyond real. The areas each have an unique feel to them and are very detailed. Only downside are the resulting fps, especially in some outside areas.  I also really enjoyed the story since it's solid, fun to follow and the characters feel authentic. Scattered around the map are countless letters and audiologs to find which tell tales of long gone individuals, like the man who chased the prophet. It felt very rewarding finding a new part of his story every now and then, since it also gives you more insight into the current storyline itself.  The gameplay recieved some upgrades as well, so it's even more fun to explore the relatively open maps, climb mountains, hunt for animal loot and decide for yourself which quests you want to do next. The game rewards you for exploring the area by finding weapon parts to unlock new weapons, single weapon accessories and so on. Gathering ressources enables you to modify weapons, improving their respective stats. By leveling up while playing and collecting stuff you can unlock skills which improve various general and weapon specific aspects of Lara, which is also rewarding.  The game offers at least 20 hours of gameplay without looking for all the collectibles. At this point I played it 25 hours and reached overall progress of 86%, so there are many more collectibles to find  I highly recommend Rise of the Tomb Raider. It's a must buy!

Pros - All the stuffs you liked about the reboot comes back in better form, if you enjoyed the last one you will LOVE this one. The tombs are also MUCH MUCH better than the reboot, more complex, challenging and worth exploring. The game actually deserves to be called Tomb Raider now.  - Graphics...OMG  - replayability. The reboot suffered from a lack of replayability IMO. Instead of giving us a mediocre multiplayer, CD made the right call by giving us several new SP modes that greatly enhanced replayability. I really love the 'card' features of the game that allow you to replay the game or just a chapter with modifiers, for example you can replay a chapter with maxed out gears and try it on the highest difficulty. There are also player created missions with different objectives.  - Finally there is the Endurance mode (which, unfortunately, is sold separately for 10$). If you like a survival type of game mode that desperately tries to get you killed you will love this (Frostfall in Skyrim anyone?). The game basically gives you a small openworld to roam around, but different from the main game, Lara has a warmth and hunger meter that will decrease with time. You need to hunt and create/find fire to keep yourself alive, while trying to find relics in ruins and crypts and fight off/elude enemies. The slogan of 'woman vs the wild' truly comes to life and shines in this mode.   cons - the game is VERY VERY demanding. If you enjoy playing games on high/max settings with smooth performance, but doesn't have a high end PC, FORGET ABOUT PLAYING THE GAME, at least for now. You would be better off playing this on XBONE. The game seems to be very unoptimized for PC, or just unusually demanding. So many people with 980 and even 980Ti are complaning of FPS dips. The game consumes a whooping 6.1 GB of VRAM in 1080P at max settings!  I'm NOT saying that you shouldn't buy the game if you don't have the high-end gears. The game will be playable on even lower-end PC, but just note that you WILL suffer performance issues. You've been warned!  - Apparently a lot of people are experiencing stability and crashing issue. So beware of that... - microtransactions for the expedition cards. It's pretty slow to earn in-game credits that are used to buy the cards that modify the game. The game is still perfectly playable without the cards. But it's clear that the devs intentionally made earning $ a lot harder so people will feel enticed by the microtransactions.

Genuinely very impressed with this game; I've barely played it, but up until this point it's surpassed 2013's reboot in every possible way. The graphics, presentation, narrative, characters, gameplay and voice-acting has all been top-notch! Not only that, but for the price that it is for all the content you get (Main game + DLC + Season Pass), I'll say right now that if Action-Adventure coupled with good story telling in your thing, then BUY THIS GAME.  One of my biggest concerns with the prequel was that I felt they handled Lara's development haphazardly; I found that Lara was thrust into nigh on impossible situations too early on within the story, not allowing for a gradual build-up of her experience. I won't go into the details, but suffice to say a weakened human being would be highly unlikely to suffice the events she found herself in, though I understand with such games/stories a lot of this is done to drive the plot and make the gameplay engaging. Otherwise, for a reboot I found it to be an extremely well-designed title and my hats off to Crystal Dynamics for not only doing the franchise justice but also for creating a sequel that goes beyond my expectations.  I'll allow others to experience for themselves what this game is like, but I'll say this much; every system and gameplay mechanic has been substantially improved for this title, and really hammers home the idea of survival.  The only problem I have with this iteration is the use of the Q key/Survival Instincts, which is too prevelant. Sure, you don't have to use it, but it's functionality is so ingrained into the game's mechanics (enemy positions, resources, extras) and necessary for some essential parts (objects can be blended too well with the environment). I think it's a cop-out when developers do this, and honestly it's just a cheap way of making the game more accessible. Furthermore, as far as I'm concerned if you have to implement such a feature in the first place then they've not done a good job adding these elements to the game in the first place. The recent Batman titles did the same thing with X-ray vision, and I feel it just distracts from the experience.  Overall, a worthy successor to the reboot and entry to the franchise. This game and developer deserves your money and praise.

Normally I'm not a fan of linear games, but this one I like. And it's weird because I'll be climbing along a cliff side, and the rock I'm clinging to will crumble away and fall along with me, and In the midst of my fall I will wonder not whether or not I'm going to survive the fall, but how in the world am I going to get back because there only seems to be one path available to any given place in this game. And the reason I tolerate this, I think, is because the sacrifice of logic is made to be worth it with exhilerating moments of engagement in the story. I feel what Lara is feeling when something goes wrong with my only plan, and I'm left with no apparent options, I feel trapped even though I'm not, but Lara is, and suddenly I find a solution, and it feels like a miracle. Experiencing the miracles are what redeems the logical falacies, and trapping nature of linear games. Just based on this I would recommend this game, but there are some things that may make some of you hesitate in buying it, and I'd like to warn you of those.   The most noteworthy is the grinding required to aquire certain things. This warning is only for those of you who happen to not want to perform genocide on wildlife that is nearly equatable in magnitude to the holocaust in order to attain the best bow, rifle, pistol, or shotgun upgrades for any or all of the variants of these weapons. I say this because the crafting requirements for weapon upgrades often requires many resources from animals. To be fair you can go through the game without destroying local ecosystems because the weapon upgrades are not entirely necessary, but if you are a perfectionest with a conscience you may be putting yourself into a terrible predicament by playing this game.  The other reason you may not want to buy this game is because you won't get much time out of it. Like I said it's a linear game so there's not much replayability to be had, and all the game has to offer to keep you engaged after you have finished the story is a thing called expeditions, which basically allows you to repeat specific parts of the story with arcade-like challenges. I find these boring, and I don't think they are good enough to maintain my interest in the game. I finished the story in about 19 hours, but you may finish the game in less if you don't get caught up in slaughtering the wildlife, so if you think <19 hours of a great story is worth 60 dollars minus 1 cent then I recommend you get this game, if not wait for a sale, or just don't buy it.

So, I wanted to beat this before I wrote a review. When I finished, I had completed roughly 70% of the content. I missed a few of the tombs, but saw enough to know what they were like, and some of the weapon components.  All in all, this was a solid game, but not something I would recommend buying at full price for two reasons: 1) There isn't all that much gameplay to be had and 2) Though it's well done, there's nothing life-changing here. The most I'd pay, if I could do it again, is 40 dollars.  This is a nonexhaustive review, I listed the things that I've most commonly seen commented on and anything that jumped out at me.  TLDR: Good graphics, but mundane setting. Decent story, but a bit short. Average overall mechanics (crafting, combat). Enjoyed my time played, but less than the former title. Though i recommend it, I would not pay more than 40 dollars.  Pros:  - Graphics. The graphics are extremely well done. There is a lot of polish, nothing too clunky (the occasional visual glitch)  - Tombs. Tombs were pretty solid; simple enough that they wouldn't totally frustrate you, but not so mindlessly easy that they had no value.  - Story. This would probably be more appropriately listed in the 'neutral' category. I didn't find the story particularly thrilling. It was extremely straightforward, there were not any exciting twists. However, it was good enough to keep me playing and did not detract from my experience at all. Given that I wanted to see how it ended, even though the end was predictable, I suppose I have to consider it a 'pro'. Though, I'll finish a terrible book just to validate my own opinion, so this might not be a legitimate criterion to use.   Neutral:  - I found the gathering/crafting to be fairly mundane. There are a lot of different supplies to collect throughout your journey, but all recipes are standard: X, Y, Z, press button, new item. It did not detract from my experience, but - other than the weapons - it did not add much either. Given that the crafting felt like an afterthought, the game could have benefitted from fewer crafting components (I cannot believe I'm typing this). I spent a fair amount of time collecting things and killing random animals, but still could not craft a lot of items because I was frequently missing a component. Again, this did not hurt the experience, but it did not improve it either; it's possible I would have felt a greater sense of achievement if I were able to craft some of the items more easily. Either way, it probably does not really matter.  - Combat was average to me. I have read a lot of reviews that think it was better than the last Tomb Raider, but I don't understand why. The combat itself played the same, with a few minor changes. There was significantly less of it, which seems to be why people prefer combat in this game more than in the last. The reason I disliked it is because it was so damn scripted. Maybe a tomb raider game shouldn't have a lot of combat, but the reduction resulted in a gameplay style of: explore for awhile, cut scene, scripted encounter; explore for awhile, cut scene, scripted encounter. For me, it felt entirely too forced.  Cons:  - The setting. Graphically, I found the game mesmerizing. Unfortunately, the setting rarely gives the graphical depth a chance to shine. Most of your time is spent in a colorless, snowy scenery. Don't get me wrong, I love the snow, but there are only so many shades of white before it all just looks the same. When I finally made it to a setting with color, I was blown away. Sadly, very little of your time is spent in areas where the graphics truly get to show off.   - Linear. This might not be the best way to describe this, because there is definitely room for exploration. However, much of this game just felt too linearly scripted for me. You frequently bump into 'gates' (ie haven't unlocked an item that you gain access to later) that break up immersion. Initially, it did not bother me much. I figured, 'well, that's realistic, I guess'. Unfortunately, it happened so frequently while I randomly explored that eventually it dissuaded me from continuing to explore. Not necessarily the game's fault as some of that is of my own volition. The game doesn't do itself any favors in this category, though.

Be warned though it's like Crysis, you need an incredibly powerful rig to run it once you get to the lost city stages. My frame rate on an r290 fluctuates wildly from 60fps down to the teens on the high setting and tessellation set to 8x in crimson control panel, playing only 1080p. This is with the latest beta driver. I thoroughly disagree with the reviewers who say there's not much difference between the quality settings, there is a gulf. If you have the rig to run this congrats, I thought meeting the recommended specs was enough but it's sadly not at least on AMD. A g-sync or free-sync monitor is recommended to address the frame rate fluctuations. I am hoping they can add further optimisations to the frame rate because it really struggles in parts. Can consume up to 7gb of video ram on highest texture settings, even on high it's saturated my r290 4GB buffer. But boy it can look beautiful.  Update: I have updated this section now that I have tested the latest AMD Driver 15.3.1 and the new Patch which both support DirectX 12. This game is incredibly single core heavy in DirectX 11 mode, even an overclocked FX processor (my 8320 is running @ 4.7Ghz) is not fast enough to smoothly run this game. However with the DirectX12 support now added, the game spreads the load evenly across all the cores eliminating the large frame rate fluctuations. Coupled with AMD's optimisations and the game can easily hold 50fps just about all the time and closes in on the golden 60fps on the default High game setting at 1080p. There are still a few demanding areas but these drop to the 40s instead of the teens now so they aren't are noticable unless you are looking for them.  The future of AMD and DirectX 12 looks quite rosy ;)

Following the very enjoyable Tomb Raider reboot in 2013 I must admit many tears were shed when Square Enix announced that the follow up game would only be available on the Xbox. Sadly for kleenex share prices this lunacy did not last for long as the accountants had a quiet word in the shell-like ears of the marketing guys and explained that this was the worst idea since someone said 'yeah let's take this suspiciously large horse into Troy, statues are all the rage this season'.  However after my experience pre-ordering Arkham Knight, my anticipation was a little muted and I have held off on buying Rise of the Tomb Raider until a few days ago. After playing the game, my trepidation has proven to have been somewhat unfounded, though not enough for me to ever consider pre-ordering a game again (once bitten and what not).  So how does RotTR stand up compared to it's 2013 predecessor? Quite well actually, it's pretty enjoyable. It feels like a progression and there are definite improvements from the first installment. You have alot more weapons to choose from, and rather than weapon types being upgraded you now have the option to select the paticular type of pistol, bow, shotgun and rifle you want to equip. So if you are going huntng, you'll want to equip the powerful bolt rifle which will kill most animals with just one well place shot, but if you are entering into a fire fight with a half dozen or more enemies you need to think about equipping a machine gun with a much larger magazine (something that caught me out on my first play through). Also included are improvised weapons that can be crafted from jerry cans, bottles, baked bean tins, walkie talkies and chickens (yes you read that right) which can then be thrown at enemies or left as booby traps which is a nice touch. The skill trees have been enlarged and improved and affect how you choose to (or even can) play the game. Now each time you level up, you can choose to focus on skills that will give you an advantage if stealth is your prefered option, conversely if you like running into a room gung-ho all guns blazing there are skills available to help with that too. Another improved aspect to RotTR is the tombs, they are better hidden and once you are there they will take a bit more figuring out that in the TR reboot, so you get more of a sense of achievement when you reach your goal. And finally for the pros are the different outfits available, they now serve a purpose rather than just being aesthetic as many will come with bonuses that will help Lara through her quest  What I would say though is that this game does have a couple of issues. Now I am a big fan of the Assassin's Creed and Arkham franchises and enjoyed the Tomb Raider reboot as much as the first game from those two series. I was hoping that RotTR would be to TR what Arkham City was to Arkham Assylum. It is though more along the lines of what AC IV: Black Flag was to ACIII. Now don't get me wrong, I have got many hours of fun out of AC III & IV, but they felt like very similar games apart from a few small improvements from III to IV (the sea battles and buliding of your fleet of ships for example). For all of the improvements of gear and tombs, this is something that RotTR also suffers from. The main antagonist felt very familiar, as did parts of the landscape. Certain levels looked and felt like I had gone through them before in the prequel and all of the enemies felt like a rehash of those who were in Lara's way in the reboot, even the 'plot twists' you can see coming from a mile off. All of which was more than a little dissapointing.  Minor quibbles aside though, this is another good installment of the tales of Lara Croft and I reccomend that anyone who played the reboot and enjoyed it should get this also as they will have fun scaling rock walls, skulking through gulags, hunting wolves and blowing up helicopters. I look forwards to the next installment.  A solid 8/10 game.

In fact I came back to finish this game because I scored a 32' 4K UHD IPS screen paired with a GTX1080 and the visuals so impressed me I started playing games again in general. I enjoy a good story and I was not disappointed. With multiple characters and a strong story arc it is something we have come to expect from the franchise and we have not been let down. While I found Lara a bit too fragile for my liking it was interesting and somewhat engaging. I can't quite put my finger on it but for some reason I wasn't cheering Lara on. I was more watching her with an observers eye as I couldn't really empathise with her as I would have thought. I am not really sure I like it that much. While it adds an element of the macabre it pulls me out of the moment. Does everything have to result in immediate death? Maybe this is just a way to avoid having an impairment system which I feel would be more realistic to the story.  Overall it is a tremendous achievement. A balls to the wall romp through and adventure where death awaits around every corner. Beautifully detailed and technically excellent I can't help but recommend this game to others.

In a nutshell, the Rise of the Tomb Raider is a logical continuation of the 2013 Tomb Raider, and plays very much like its predecessor, but with many small enhancements to the formula. If you enjoyed the previous Tomb Raider, you'll definitely like this one as well.  I loved the visuals, the environment was absolutely gorgeous with detailed animations and beautiful art design. Facial motion capture really brought cutscenes to the next level, and the significantly improved lighting seals the deal to make this one of the best looking role-playing titles to date.  The game has noticeably more to explore this time around, and many more actual tombs to solve. I was surprised by the variety of tombs that the game had to offer; no two were alike, yet all presented a fun and reasonable challenge. Also a tip of the hat to Crystal Dynamics for not walling off parts of the game behind DLC. There is a season pass available, but the crucial thing is that the game has plenty of content and feels complete without it.  The game mechanics are very similar to the previous Tomb Raider. Cover-based combat and stealth approaches once again give the player multiple ways to play the game. The climbing, shooting, and loot collecting are smooth as clockwork, and the enhanced crafting system now allows you to craft ammo on the run.  I do however have a few gripes with this game. It is undoubtably very good, but not quite 'great' in my opinion. The thing that bothered me the most is the lackluster writing. If you finish the game and think about it for a minute, you might notice that some aspects don't really make sense. Without spoiling the story, I'll just say that the 'guardians' of the 'treasure' have no real reason to treat Lara and the bad guys differently if their true goal is to keep the 'treasure' hidden at all costs. I was a bit surprised by a plot twist late in the game, but other than that, most of it was quite predictable.   Lastly, I would like to mention that in order to experience this game in all its visual glory, you will need a bit of power in your rig. It is a demanding title, but in my opinion not unoptimized. I played through the game maxed out at 1080p(with FXAA), and was able to maintain a smooth 60FPS most of the time with a GTX 980 and i5 4670K, but my framerates did drop into the 40FPS range in large and open environments.  I'm generally a sucker for good graphics and eye candy, but I do value a good story. For the Rise of the Tomb Raider, my final verdict is a solid 'B+', and I would recommend this game to those who might enjoy an RPG with a blend of action and puzzles.

Having played through Rise of the Tomb Raider on xbox one upon release and thoroughly enjoying it I can safely say that I'm thrilled that its come to PC so quickly. Had I known the wait for the PC release would be a mere few months rather than say the best part of a year or so I would've held out for sure.   System Spec: Skylake i5 6600k 3.5 ghz  Asus Strix GTX 960 2GB  16GB DDR4 RAM 2133mhz   As mentioned earlier however the xbox one version was certainly no slouch and is still actually very impressive to look at alongside the PC version which leads me to discuss the game's scalability. From the outset you're going to need at least a mid to high end gaming PC to get the job done to any degree of satisfaction. The low settings do indeed take a drastic dip in quality and lag behind the xbox one version significantly. On medium to high settings on a modest rig like mine however you can achieve between 60 and 40 fps dependent on the situation (although I'd recommend overclocking your GPU a little at the very least). You might just be able to scrape by with your trusty 750Ti on lower settings as long as you're rocking a quad core or higher CPU as this appears to have significant bearing on the game's performance.   As a whole however despite many outlets raising concerns about performance and frame rate issues I've yet to actually encounter any myself aside from the normal dips in frame rate caused by demanding scenes or areas. I'm really quite happy with the performance even on a 2gb gtx 960.  Gameplay and atmosphere wise I really can't get enough of the game. The Siberian wilderness provides an excellent backdrop with your vision often obscured by snowy storms or dimly lit caverns however these make way to gorgeous locales such as the galleon frozen into a glacier or the sprawling vistas of snowy landscape. There are sections that mix up the snowy areas however which makes for some variety in the environments, Lara's movement and animations are slick and refined which makes the whole experience a joy to play through, enemy AI is up to snuff and requires you to constantly be thinking on your feet because they will quickly overwhelm you if you attempt to camp out and stay put in combat situations. The way the enemies behave really pushes you to make maximum use of the skills and crafting available to you.   If you're into exploration and seeking out new areas there is a plethora of interesting places to visit within the map which will often see you back tracking. However this doesn't feel like re-treading old ground rather becoming more familiar with the world which arguably increases your immersion and investment in the whole affair. It does become rather tricky to remember where exactly certain locations are however and you may often find yourself going from place to place before stumbling upon the location you were after.   As a whole however there are few faults to pick with the game aside from the common gripes found within the genre such as occasional bouts of repetitive gameplay and the plot is a bit hokey but then again in this genre I think its almost a right of passage now as far as plot goes. The acting in the game however is superb and draws you in far deeper than you might imagine.   This is one of those games that I can happily play through multiple times achieving a varied experience and simply enjoying the hell out of it for what it is.   This is one of the few games that I would actually place on that lofty 10/10 pedestal. Not that the games perfect but in my mind I found everything I wanted from the game and feel thoroughly fullfiled by the whole package. I should state that the xbox one version would probably only achieve a 9 mostly due to the PC just being able to bring out those more subtle world building elements of realism thanks to the application of 60 frames per second and the extra bells and wistles.   In closing, I have no reservations about recommending this game to anyone even at full price.

Let's face it, Tomb Raider didn't need a second reboot. 2006's Anniversary/Legend/Underworld trilogy was pretty darn good, and this is just a money-making venture.  However that doesn't make this or 2013's reboot bad games, far from it. The original was a lot of fun, beautiful, and while the ending sequence of it all being to do with weather control was a tad far-fetched, it made it no less fun.  This sequel to that manages to expand the depth of the story, and does a far better of fleshing out the characters, but performance issues and a weak final section rather diminish the overall quality.  Rise of the Tomb Raider, which, in all honesty, the original from three years ago could have been called, unless it was being literal, is a truly engaging game with breathtaking visuals including a quite stunning looking Lara who is probably the best ever cut-scene real-time rendered character ever seen in a game. It also manages to maintain the gameplay from the original while expanding the tools and general depth of side missions. There is a furious amount of depth in this game, and a furious number of side bits and bobs you can do.  The environments look...well...stunning, frankly, and while performance issues affect a couple of them, generally the areas look impeccable.  If you've played the original you'll fit into this one like a glove, but the big let down is the final section. It's big, it's long, and for all its pretty looks, it's boring to play - it's incredibly derivative and feels like a copy of the final area of the original - the boss fights are also a stroll and don't really create tension - one other review called this game easy - yes, it definitely isn't a tough game. One or two bits might see a few deaths but generally the challenge is minimal.  There is also the flaw that Lara has now become a bit superhuman. Sure, she always was, but with this reboot they've tried to make her real. Unfortunately when she flies through the air and grabs a ledge she has no right to get close to, it detracts from the realism.  The voice acting is good, even if the plot itself, while engaging, is ultimately a bit empty - there is also no reference to any characters from the original beyond Lara and Jonah who has a slightly higher than a cameo role in this.  It's a good game, very good, but that weak final section and some technical problems stop it from being truly memorable.

It's 'ok'.  For all the the first of the two 'reboot' Tomb Raiders by Crystal Dynamics had A LOT of things that GREATLY irked me (i.e. 100,000 quicktime events, Laura either falling from 10+ stories or getting 'captured' every 5 feet, and the plot with the other crew members playing out like a back 'slasher' film, etc.), I still found it MUCH more 'enjoyable' than this one, for the following reasons:  1) Exploration rewarded you. There was ONE map/chart per area that 'marked' the location of all the items onto your zone map. In this version, there's A LOT more 'AAA game hand-holding', and each zone has anywhere from 3-10 different things that will 'show' tiny parts of what you can find on the map. ...And if that wasn't annoying enough for you, most of the 'hey look over here' maps/charts are laid out DIRECTLY on the 'story path', so you would have needed to suffer MANY blows to the head to miss them...  2) Ironically, while the zones themselves at first impression SEEM much larger and more 'openly explorable', it's actually a facade, and they are EXTREMELY linear as far as how much you are 'allowed' to explore - you have to backtrack TONS more than in the first game after ytou reach the arbiotrary story point at which you gain the item needed to uplock more of the zone. One of the ones that irked me the most was that the tombs themselves (i.e. the fun parts of the games where all the ACTUAL 'TOmb Raide-raiding tombs puzzels' were hiding) were almost UNANIMOUSLY 'locked off' until you progressed far ebnough into the sotyline to gain the item to get inside them. What's worse is that VERY often the 'item' needed to gain entry to said tombs WASN'T EVEN THEN USED AS PART OF THE TOMB'S PUZZLE (i.e. the one that required the 'rebreather' for Laura to swim more than 10 meteres without drowning or something, cuz ya know, it's not like all that mountain climbing in thin atmosphere envirnonments woulda naturally given her a much larger lung capacity and tollerance for less oxygen! Oh wait...).  3) The actual 'Tomb Puzzles' were more 'linear' than in the last game, and I found the 'solutions' t be a lot simpler and easier to figure out as well. Now, I don't mean 'linear' in the sense of 'only one path' in this case, what I mean is that you may be carrying 5+ different things that *LOGICALLY* would have functionally solved the challenge presented to you, but ONLY the one Crystal Dynamics 'thought of' will work, so it turn into a game of 'die until I figure out how YOU want me to solve this puzzle'...  I wanna get some *special* hate on for a 'round robin boat pulling' tomb that took me EONS to 'figure out', cuz the boats themselves did not behave 'naturally' - they did not follow the current of the river, and their behavior 'changed' as soon as yopu jumped onto one of them as well (and while I was QUITE capabale of simply 'jumping' to where I needed to go FROM one of the boats, it would not let me 'ledge grab' until I was on the 'correct' boat...). I mean, what is this - a 90's adventure game!?  4) The 'coin collection' aspect of the game was TERRIBLY managed. You may have walked DFIRECTLY over the SPECIFIC location where a 'coin cache' was burried 100+ times, but until you find the SPECIFIC map/chart that TELLS you it's 'burried there', and give you a map marker for it, you can't loot them. While you could argue this means 'go fnd the maps/charts', in reality it means 'stop having fun freely exploring and progress into the story until we HAND you the map/chart along the story path where you can't miss it...).  5) The combat is basically unchanged since the first one. Sure, you can 'craft bombs' and 'switch out weapon types', but the effects of changing weapons were superficial at best, and some of the 'perks' for setting traps were COMPLETELY pointless, such as the 'turn enemy radios into proximity mines', and 'turn enemy bodies into poison traps'. I honestly got throught the ENTIRE game not getting to try either of these even ONCE (and almost ALL of my kills were 'stealth kills' as well), simply because the locations were enemies will actually DROP their radios are rigidly determined, and none of them let you take the 'crafted proximitiy mine' to the next enemy encounter. As for the 'dead body trap' thing, this has more to do with the enemy AI zoning - you would need to: A) Kill an enemy from stealth with more enemies remaining in the area. B) Have his body be in the open and 'visible' to other enemies (nearly impossible to do with 'stealth kills'). C) Not get 'spotted' at all, or they wouldn't 'check the body'.  6) I was kinda sad that rope arrows became 'contexztual only' - I had so many laughs in the first game using them to yank enemies off cliffs! XD  ----- So in summery, I really don't recommend this to anyone who wants to explore and play fun, thought provoking puzzles. I would highly recommend the first one over this one, but even so, I still think it's better than a lot of the garbage comming out of late from the AAA circle, so I will give the game a *tentative* 'yes' (if Steam offered a 'horizontal thumb' 'Meh' option, though, I'd be picking that one... >_<).

Well, the story starts out real well, but then gets kinda stale. I loved the beginning sections in Syria and on the mountain during the storm, but after that, compared to 2013, I felt like I was in the same area the whole time. There definitely wasn't enough exploration. And to make it worse, the maps are absolutely cluttered with collectibles, hundreds and hundreds of pointless collectibles. Just like the collectibles, these really take away from the story, which is the main mechanic of this game.   Overall,  it's not bad, it's just not what it should have been. Even though the 2013 game took place on a single island, the environment constantly changed as you progressed. Rise of the Tomb Raider isn't like that. I enjoyed Tomb Raider's 2013 reboot more than I thought I would. I got it on sale, and was pleasantly surprised by the fact that the devs managed not to mangle one of the best-know game series out there. Given how good the reboot was and all that I'd heard about the next entry in the series, I was pretty excited for Rise.   The game mostly met my expectations, but didn't do much to blow my doors off. Once the (really bad) optimization issues were fixed, Rise looked beautiful and ran smoothly on high/very settings (970 FTW, i5 4690k, 8 GB RAM). The game's lighting is particularly noteworthy. It's amazing to look at a chem light's distorted reflection in a massive icicle.   On the gameplay side, things are decent. The platforming is fun (if a little spotty in places), the shooting feels much tighter than it did in the previous game, and the scripted moments are very intense. Yet a lot of the game feels a bit soulless to me. I found the skill trees shockingly mundane and often boring, to the point that I stopped spending skill points roughly halfway through the game. It just never felt worth it, and none of them seemed to alter gameplay enough to even justify the time it took to pick them. Similarly, the crafting system feels bolted on. Sure, you can add fancy barrels and extended magazines and the ability to quickly shoot three arrows, but you really don't need to. Combat encounters are infrequent, and they not particularly hard to survive even with iffy equipment.   Worse, much of the game feels restrictively scripted. Many combat encounters allow for stealth, but many others force you into guns-blazing battles for no apparent reason. The side missions feel bolted on as padding; I never felt interested or excited about 'clear out this cave' or 'kill four boars' quests for random faceless NPC #33,575. And because the skill points don't seem all that valuable, I was never given much of an incentive to do these missions other than to artificially extend my time with the game.   Even the open-world(ish) hub areas feel dull and lifeless. They're pretty, sure, but they just don't sing the way I'd hoped they would. They have no character, no life. Some of this problem may be due to the fact that there are patently obvious game signals everywhere--bare tree trunks you can climb, special walls to jump onto, rope pillars and pulleys to attach to stuff. I like the mechanics of the game, and I dug using most of Lara's moves and equipment. But the omnipresence of these signals never lets you forget you're playing a game, which seriously dings immersion. It's really hard to feel like you're in a real place when glowing objects, beams of light, and obvious interactive textures constantly remind you that you are playing a game.   Speaking of immersion, I was let down by the story. I appreciate the attempt to give the narrative some emotional weight, but I didn't connect with Lara in this iteration like I did in the last one. I didn't really care about Lara's daddy issues or self-righteous quest for vindication the same way I cared about her when she was hurt, scared, and vulnerable in the first game. Battle-hardened Lara Croft is a bad mama, but her badass-ery comes at the expense of the humanity that made the 2013 game so great.  Similarly, most of the supporting characters are so archetypical and two dimensional that I just couldn't bring myself to be interested in them. The villains, in particular, are flat, boring, and predictable. None of this is helped by the fact that that game's overarching narrative is the same as always in Tomb Raider: Lara must find ancient, powerful artifact before bad guys do. Oh, and she wants to redeem her dad's reputation. But mostly she just wants that shiny thing. The writers tried to spice things up with a couple of twists, but I saw the big one coming many hours before it happened. And when the big reveal finally occurred, it landed with pretty noticeable thud.   Where the game really shines is the optional tombs. These are genuinely interesting, and each one is unique. I very much enjoyed the ambience and story behind each tomb, and I found the puzzles--each of the tombs is based around a large environmental puzzle--to be challenging, interesting, and fun. Truth be told, I would happily pay $60 for a larger collection of these tombs, especially given the weakness of the game's overall story.   All told, I finished the game in about 16 hours. I didn't do all of the side content, but I did a fair amount of it, including the optional tombs I found. I don't have much interest in running around playing chase the icon to gather all the arbitrary stuff and complete all the arbitrary tasks needed to reach 100 percent. And because the story wasn't exactly the most compelling I've ever seen, I doubt I'll play this again any time in the near future. That's kind of a shame, really, because Rise has a lot of potential.  I hope the next iteration of Tomb Raider moves away fom the tightly scripted, gamey conventions of this entry and toward the much, much (MUCH) more enjoyable tombs, puzzles, and exploration that prop Rise up despite its faults. For now, I'd recommend that all outside of the most diehard completionists wait to pick this one up on sale.

Is this a good game? Yes. Is it better than the first one in 2013? Absolutly.  Congrats to Square Enix! A rare thing happened with this game: this is a direct upgrade to the first one. The only thing that's worse is the story, which I feel is more interesting in 2013, but damn. The gameplay is the same, but improved. There's a lot more to do, a lot more secondary tombs, lots of weapon upgrades and interesting Lara upgrades. And the Challenge mode only asks us to play some chapters again.

Quite an enjoyable game, but the best part about it is actually the Endurance DLC. I recommend it for fans of TR 2013 and action movies. Do not recommend to people who expect a sophisticated story or are easily bothered by deus ex machina.  GRAPHICS: As with the previous title in the series, this game has absolutely stunning visuals. It does have issues with DX12 implementation however. It is a great game for resolutions above 1080p, as it has plenty of fine detail in grass, leaves etc that will show off the clarity of higher resolutions. Lara gets some sick hair physics, while other characters' hair gets some movement. There's some quality motion capture that really shines in close up cutscenes, and also it is nice to see a female protaganist with a range of outfits which for the most part are weather-appropriate.  STORY: Nothing particularly noteworthy here. Plenty of documents to give added insight around the main plot if you look hard enough, but the underlying story is kind of underwhelming. It is presented in a Hollywood-style fashion - not a lot of flesh, but a lot of production sparkle to distract from it. It is at least a human story with displays of emotion.  CORE GAMEPLAY: There is a mix of linear story sections and open areas to explore. Exploration has some rewarding moments here and there, and really shows off the visual quality of the game. Platforming is interesting but not particularly challenging - you can't accidentally walk off edges, camera usually points you in the direction you need to go, but there is enough variety in there to keep it from getting too repetitive. There are a lot of story sections in which you're escaping a structure that collapses around you or something of the sort - it is overused and melodramatic but you will die if you get sloppy, giving the scenes at least a sense of urgency. Puzzles are a good difficulty level - tricky enough to make you stop and think, but not enough to stall out the flow of the game. I would have preferred them a little longer however. Crafting and skills are more advanced than TR 2013, but still relatively simple.  COMBAT: Decent, but flawed. If you have decent aim I would not recomment playing on any less than Seasoned Raider. Some enemies will constantly throw explosives at you, forcing you to constantly dodge, while giving little real challenge. Headshots are overpowered as ♥♥♥♥. Melee feels a little awkward, especially on mouse + keyboard, but is useful and useable. Weapon variety has improved, with 3-4 different variations in each weapon category (bow, pistol, rifle, shotgun), 3 different types of special arrows, and craftable throwables such as molotovs and shrapnel grenades. It's a shame that most of the time this is reduced to your headshot scorer of choice. Stealth is a little disappointing; you have a variety of stealth tools at your disposal, however with no ability to move bodies, limited hiding abilities and many forced firefights through the story, it is difficult to maintain stealth long enough for it to be satisfying. The highlights would be the special arrows and the craftables; if you use these with body shots, combat is reasonably fun - until enemies spam explosives or you realise that headshots are just so much more effective.  ENDURANCE DLC: This is a good enough game mode to get it's own section. Seriously, I wish Crystal Dynamics made an entire game based on this. It's a lot more accessible than many of the online survival games out there where you can't reasonably survive as a solo player and/or will die a lot in the process of learning the game's mechanics. In Endurance Mode, Lara has to eat to offset starvation, and warm up by fireplaces to offset hypothermia, and if you neglect one of these you will die. You can select challenges to complete each run, as well as game-modifying cards, and then when you either escape or die you earn credits from these challenges and any artifacts you escape with, which can then be used to purchase randomised packs of cards. You have access to the full skill tree and upgrades menu for all weapons you pick up from fallen enemies, some of which are very useful, others less so. This mode actually offers better stealth action than the core game thanks to increased manouvering space and more serious consequences. Fights with bears, great cats and the harder versions of the human enemies are tenser than any fight in the core came too. The real letdown here is that there is only one map available currently, and two different layouts for crypts discovered. I also experienced game crashes at around the 5 day point, which I managed to solve by backdating to a previous version of the game.  SOUND: Stellar. The soundtrack is very well crafted builds great tension, and responds dynamically to the level of danger ingame with multiple levels of intensity. Voice acting is generally quite good, in spite of the mediocre story. Sound effects have quality to match. I will also add here that listening for animal sounds is quite important in Endurance mode; it's nice to know if you're walking approximately towards a bear, especially if you're out of poison arrows.  OVERALL: This review probably sounds like a mixed review - but I definitely feel positive about the game. It does have its flaws, but the overall experience is great for the most part. If you allow yourself to be wowed by it's good qualities, you might just find yourself forgiving it for its shortcomings as I did.

An amazing return to the adventures of Lara Croft. Even better than the original reboot released a couple years ago. First, I'm running on dual Sapphire Tri-X R290s in Xfire with everything cranked up to High or Ultra (if allowable) and the game ran fantastic. Also running an AMD FX 8350 on an Asus Sabertooth 990FX gen 3 with 16GB of Ripjaw on a 1TB WD Velociraptor. Now, with that out of the way, moving on.   As you may be able to tell from the stills on the Store Page, the game looks absolutely fantastic with everything up High. Environments are crisp and detailed. Small things like foot marks left from trudging through the snow, crisp winter air being exhaled and the hair all look phenomenal. Character design is top notch and character movement is swift and on point. Everything from the ground textures to the trees to the tomb designs are all very detailed and very well done.    Sound design is what you'd expect from CD. Full 5.1 surround implemented with ambient localization to character placement. Very nicely done. Guns have a nice pop, the twang of the bow being pulled and released is deadly accurate and the voice acting is top notch. Music takes the normal approach of being soft and subtle until you get into a fight or battle then expect to hear the pounding drums and native flutes bouying over the air to your attempts at staying alive.    The level design is a lot more open this time around. There are larger areas that have multiple avenues of exploration and camping allowed as well as many secrets that won't be found until a later return afer some upgrades have happened. There are different levels of exploration in this Tomb Raider. Beginning with the game's exploration of open areas, the tombs that have been amped up and many different iterations and lastly with the secret hunt quests that begin when you do certain actions. All well done and nicely implemented into the whole of its parts.    There's a really nice upgrade path this time around, similar to the reboot, and while allowing the basic avenues of upgrading Lara's abilities, I would have liked to see it have maybe a few more options when going down either of the 3 paths in the game. While some are interesting, some are your 'average' upgrades. Things like more health, or able to take more punishment would have been nicely tied into upgrading your equipment and clothing to include maybe some ballistic panels or whatnot. Still, it's nicely done and will have you thinking for a few minutes while you choose your path in this game.    The story arc is well written and extemely well voice acted. While the story does take some dips here and there, the story makes a case of being well prepared and ready for anything while adventuring. Lara is again the highlight of the game and is so fluid in her character design decisions and acting that it's completely believable in the end. Villain arcs are ripped right of the 'bad guy handbook' and, while done well, could have been a bit more interesting in the long run. The game took me about 30 hours and that was with heavy exploring and hunting, going for certain upgrades, etc. I never once thought the game's pacing was taking too long and was thoroughly enjoyed with my entire romp in the completely believable world that has been created for us.    While I won't give away and spoilers I will say this. The game ends with a little something that lets us know there will be another Tomb Raider at some point, and personally, I can't wait to get my hands on it if it's anywhere near as fantastic as the past two games have been.

The Good: Fantastic visuals, Lara Croft is still a wonderful character, huge open world to explore with more to find, entertaining story  The Bad: All the weapon upgrades feel useless compared to the easy and generic enemies, story loses focus on Lara's character development, no reason to get 100% unless you're a completionist  Tomb Raider (2012) was a revolutionary game for the franchise and genre as a whole. It took the game industry by storm with its cinematic gameplay, fantastic visuals, huge open world, and realism. What could Crystal Dynamics do to top this you ask? It's pretty hard to top that and they didn't quite top it this time around. Rise of the Tomb Raider is more of what we got before and not much else but that's not a bad thing.  The game doesn't focus so much on Lara's survival to get back home but more on her treasure hunting. There's an item called the Divine Source that grants people immortality. It's something that her father obsessed on and ultimately got him killed. A mercenary group called Trinity wants this source so it's Lara's job to go and retrieve it before anyone gets their hands on it. The story is a little predictable and cheesy. It's the typical generic mercenary bad guy plot which I found uninteresting as Lara's character development was the center of the story in the last game. It's disappointing, but entertaining nonetheless.  The opening scene in RotTR is fantastic set in Tibet where you get to feel just how dangerous Lara's treks are and the environment around you. It's probably the best scene in the whole game as the developers slowly forgot what made Tomb Raider...Tomb Raider towards the end of the game like they were running out of ideas. You will notice right away the huge visual upgrade over the last game. Fantastic lighting effects, tessellation, gorgeous textures, and the character modeling is some of the best I have ever seen. The individual pores can be seen on Lara's face which is 10x more detail than the last game.  After the opening scene I realize not too much has changed from the last game control wise and the gameplay elements are nearly untouched just fine tuned. After I start trekking along in the first area I divert by exploring and finding all the hidden stuff. TR has a lot of hidden secrets to find and it's all about using your Instincts around you to find all the secrets that glow gold and finding the maps to reveal them on your map. I spent a majority of the game finding these secrets which are a blast to find however there's a Metroidvania feeling to this game. I had to acquire new equipment before I could enter certain areas especially the tombs.  While just playing the game in general I realized a few disappointing things about this game. Leveling up completely, upgrading all your guns, just like in the last game, means less this time around. The game is fairly easy, the mix between exploration, combat, and stealth are very random and spread out. I could honestly play the entire game with the pistol and I would be fine. The last game had enemies that required different weapons, but this time around Crystal didn't think about that. All the enemies are generic and there's no need to switch weapons. This is a huge blow to the games strategy that was so great in the last game. Ultimately this meant that all the side quests, gathering, and exploring could ultimately be skipped and it wouldn't make a difference. That's a really bad thing here.  Thankfully all the gameplay holds up to redeem this issue. Mainly this is here for completionists or anyone who wants to explore this gorgeous world. I think the developers forgot what was so great about TR between development cycles and it really shows here. The world was focused on so much that the stuff to fill it was pretty much forgotten. I have all these awesome weapons and upgrades, but...what do I do with them? I can craft special ammo for each weapon, but it didn't make a lick of a difference in combat. The only ammo that did was the new arrow types such as poison, explosive, and flame. Using them to take out a large group of enemies helped but that was it.  Lara also doesn't really develop more in this game. I thought the psychological stress on her from the last game would affect her here, but it's like it never happened at all. Her character is awesome as usual, but there's no more development and I feel the next game really needs to pick up on what made the first one so great. Franchise fatigue is going to set in quick here and many players may not be so excited for the next game if this keeps up.  In the end, RotTR is a fantastic game with a huge world to explore, a generic yet entertaining story, and more Lara Croft which is what we want. The biggest disappointment is there's no more character development for Lara and all these great upgrades and weapons feel useless due to the combat and enemies that didn't get any attention. The game is really easy and lacks a good challenge. The game is gorgeous, one of the best looking games ever made and continues to push PCs to their limits just like back in 2012.  ~Score: 9/10

I will keep this review as spoiler-free as I possibly can, so... here goes:  OVERALL RATING: ★★★★☆ (4/5)  Before I start this review, please note that I firmly believe that the Tomb Raider graphic novels are important if you want to know the FULL story here. They're not NECESSARY, but RECOMMENDED, should you want to understand everything that happened between Yamatai and the start of ROTTR (they do refer to things that happen in the graphic novels), so should you want a more whole story, I'd advise reading these prior to playing. They bridge the gap perfectly between the 2013 game and that which we see in ROTTR. I think they're well-worth the read, and the artwork is wonderful.  Traverse the snowy mountains and geothermal valleys as Lara does what she does best (even though what she does best seems to be butchering hundreds of people to find rusty old coins). You can see Lara wring out her hair after jumping in water, wrinkle her nose as she aims, and advance through truly breathtaking areas. I'm... I think I'm in love!  It's a fantastic game. I mean, it's amazing: it's got some interesting characters and some wonderful voice-acting, not to mention the beautiful graphics. I love the relationship between Jonah and his Little Bird (Lara). We meet some fantastic characters throughout the story. The story-arc was fantastic, with some wonderful details into both Lara's childhood and the life of Lord Croft himself...  However... that isn't to say that the story isn't without flaws. It's not a bad plot (in fact, it's wonderful), but it is quite predictable in places, and the formula is very, very, very similar to the 2013 game. Not only that, but the latter half of the story seems VERY rushed; I was under the belief that I was around half-way through the plot when BAM, I hit the point of no return. I think it could have been stretched a lot further with what they had: there were gaps in the cut-scenes I thought could have provided an interesting bit of gameplay, but alas, no such luck! It isn't a bad story by any means, but it was VERY SHORT.  The documents and relics are wonderfully detailed, and I loved listening to and reading the recordings found throughout the game. Some of the ancient text doesn't quite add-up with what Lara claims it to say, but I expected as much and so wasn't greatly disappointed. My only issue is that there are one or two grammatical errors in the writing where there shouldn't be, and it just seemed a little like nobody had bothered to proof-read some of them.   The hunting is just as good, and the crafting is a FANTASTIC improvement. I think I might be in love with the designs of the bows in particular. I really enjoyed the tracking element they added, and the outfits actually HAVE USES now (for example; stronger effects to certain things, higher carrying capacity), which is WONDERFUL.   I really enjoyed the challenge tombs in this game - I think they're a great improvement on its predecessor - and I'm pleased they game them some sort of purpose. It gave me a reason to complete them aside from wanting to see that little '100% complete' in my menu. They're also more interesting than they were in the last game, and a LOT less irritating, I found.   Graphically speaking, it's beautiful. I'm not massively bothered by graphics in games, but there were moments in the game I was utterly lost for words. The landscaping is beautiful. That's... all I really have to say about this topic.  The Baba Yaga DLC is short. Thankfully, it's not extremely expensive, but I feel that it simply fit in as a side mission with the main game. I think it made the game, overall, feel more worthwhile (I purchased the season pass with the game). I enjoyed the plot, but again, it was predictable and seemed to be cut-short.  [Expeditions will be reviewed after being played thoroughly]  I didn't encounter too many bugs in the game (impressive, considering it was only released a few days ago), though I did have to restart one or two checkpoints to trigger the next cutscenes, as they simply didn't load when they should have.  The game is, overall, brilliant (though it has its flaws). If you enjoyed the first of this reboot series, I strongly recommend this one. I really enjoyed the time I spent on it... If, however, you look for replayability, I don't think you'll enjoy this game as much as you should. I'd still recommend buying it, but if you want a lot of gameplay for your purchase, wait for it to go on sale.
