If you want this game, wait and pick it up on sale. Rise of the Tomb Raider is beautiful and the opening showed promise, but the game fell off about 15% in. Much of the trouble comes from infectious game mechanics which have permeated the modern industry, but the plot was also weak and predictable (I sussed out the big twist at the 15% point.). For your convenience as a prospective buyer, I’ve divided my impressions of the game into the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly.   The Good: Rise of the Tomb Raider is visually stunning. Playing it is much like watching a movie and the ‘cutscenes’ stitch seamlessly into the gameplay.  The platforming is enrapturing; the free-world setup of climbing and exploration makes each area a parkour playground. It was fun just running around in the wilds of the mountains. The ambiance of the world was well established and having rabbits run from your feet before a giant cat pounces you from the brush was one of the better aspects of the game.  The mini-tombs were definitively the best part of the game: encapsulated platformer puzzles hidden throughout the game gave a good breather from the (ugh) plot and made RotTR feel like a Metroidvania.   The Bad: The game implied danger; in the tutorial it explained that progress would be lost between campfires. Early in the game I believed this warning and frequently returned to campfires to save my progress. However, when I finally did die I found the game reloaded not at the last campfire but mere steps from where I had failed. The game has no risk. You don’t even lose resources (ugh) when you die, because the game autosaves after each rustled bush or kicked basket. I get that players don’t like to be frustrated, but the hand-holding in this game was excessive, particularly considering the warning.  The swarms of faceless “mooks” that you have to kill. The original Tomb Raider (for Playstation 1) stumbled onto a concept that was delightful… something the developers have failed to replicate even after two sets of reboots. In Tomb Raider, when you ran into another human being you knew that things were getting serious. They were few and far between, each was a significant threat (because their guns were actually lethal) and you had to strategize to defeat them. Doing so would give you a significant upgrade to your gear, facilitating the next branch of exploration. I felt no threat from encounters with the faceless “Trinity” forces and their endless numbers gave their deaths no meaning. I blame Uncharted and Grand Theft Auto for infecting modern gaming with this shoot-em-up mentality.  The Leveling. Any kind of immersion created by the graphics was immediately broken by the constant stream of Experience popping up after every successful action. I have no idea why modern games feel the need to have experience points; most of the upgrades could have been distributed among plot points instead. While the leveling process could be considered an acclimation to the hostile environment, it didn’t need to be so intrusive.   The Ugly:  “Crafting”. For some reason all modern games feel the need to include recipe books where you assemble junk you’ve collected from “The Wilds” (trademark) into something useful. This is the noxious contagion of that Minecraft game and its ilk and it has permeated every genre now. The crafting in this game was disgusting--you have to hunt dozens of animals to get enough scraps of hide to make a quiver for more arrows which--by the way--you don’t need anyway because you can make arrows on the fly with wood and feathers (which you find EVERYWHERE). The “resources” the game employs become layers of ammunition obfuscating your actual ammunition to the point where you just stop caring about how much stuff you have. The sad thing is this mechanic could have been turned around by circumventing the crafting lists for something cinematic. Make us hunt ONE deer to make our first quiver and then shelve that mechanic!  Lazy Lore. Superfluous content added to give the game more meat for 100%. Some of the early murals actually depicted the Prophet performing great deeds in historic venues. But… after about 15% progress the “murals” became nothing more than wall diamonds with generic text which Lara would read to fill a Language meter. That’s not a mural, it’s a plaque. If all of those little hidden “murals” had been combined into a single one with an actual image relevant to the dialogue it would have been much more satisfying.  The plot. Ugh. The plot was boring, predictable, lacked character development or motivating factors, frequently forgot important details (Oh hey, where’s Jonah? Oh, the game’s almost over, I guess I should remember I left him on the mountain now!), leaned too heavily on an infinitely powerful “secret” organization, and also depended too heavily on “That was you!?” shock drama. The sad thing is that the plot could have been salvaged with a second pass; characters had established details which were not explored and another draft before production could have improved it. By the last stretch I was so fatigued by the tired conflict I just wanted to roll credits.   What I would've done (WIWD): One: Cut the crafting. If the player goes up to a sapling and breaks off branches, just put regular arrows into their inventory. Special ammo? Using a resource node adds it to the pouch. Make ammo upgrades single-hunt side quests. Resource crafting tables are dull and need to go away.  Two: The plot. Ana’s illness should have been the driving force for Lara to seek the Source; attempting to save her step-mother’s life instead of trying to redeem her dead father’s name would have helped to make Lara more admirable and would have added some literary barbs to later events. Lara also needed to put more focus on reuniting with her friend Jonah; once she fell from the mountain she completely shrugged off her concerns for his safety… this made her unlikeable and was sloppy considering the relationship established between them before that event. “Trinity” was entirely unnecessary; Konstantin could easily have misappropriated a government force or even a private organization to suit his ends instead of being part of a faceless illuminati organization which was frankly unbelievable (any group with as many resources as were mustered in this game could not remain invisible to world governments).  Three: The mooks. Konstantin should have brought an elite force of mercenaries (like… a dozen) to the mountains to seek the Source. He didn’t need hundreds of expendable minions who were all apparently willing to fight to the death. He also didn’t need to maim them as a means of demonstrating how gruesome he was. This point also applies to Jacob; the resistance could have consisted of him and his daughter and still had meaning; in fact it would have been more moving if there were only a handful of them instead of the dozens the game presented (those dozens effectively rendering their losses faceless and meaningless). Tomb Raider shouldn’t be about clearing a bloody battlefield with an assault rifle. It should be about tombs. The game’s notes did establish backgrounds for a handful of unseen characters; if these had come around as boss fights the story’s cohesion would have been improved greatly. It would also have made the fights more memorable (I honestly can’t remember several of the zones because they were run-and-gun).  Four: The collectibles. More tombs, fewer ‘hidden item’ counts, but more meaningful finds when you come across them. If the murals had been more significant, with each improving the language skill by one instead of slowly filling a bar, encountering them would have been more exciting and thus more memorable.  The game suffers from not being memorable. It’s a pity, because it easily could have been.

Ok let's get this out of the way first, If you're after something pretty to push your expensive PC to it's limits then this game delivers, some gorgeous scenery and some of the best facial animations i've ever seen. If you're after a good game at the same time your out of luck.  *Plot*  The plot sees Lara Croft, a mutant descendant of Wolverine carrying the regeneration mutation searching for an artifact called the divine source that can give others her miraculous healing capabilities. Her journey takes her to the mountains of siberia where Lara encounters a war with the natives and templars(err i mean 'trinity') and suffers from schrodinger's hypothermia alongside everything you would expect from a tomb raider plot. It's not amazing writing that invokes great thought but your playing tomb raider, what are you after? It does what it needs to. It is an improvement on the first game however, Lara isn't yet the film Badass yet but she doesn't switch between sobbing and bloodthirsty killer every 5 seconds, supporting characters aren't underdeveloped pieces of meat who are there purely to throw in whenever the writer feels Lara hasn't faced a 'hardship' in a while and there's a Little less physical abuse to Lara’s superhuman body. The game however has a habit of completely ignoring the concept of hypothermia until it's needed for the plot and as i've been joking about this whole paragraph, Lara at least doesn’t get impaled 20 minutes in but still manages to take multiple lethal multi story falls then procede walk off holding the wound and acting like a toddler waiting for mum to kiss a small scratch better and then forgetting about it 30 seconds latter. The game also suffers from overdoing the dramatic moments, when things are crumbling around you you're supposed to get a little adrenaline burst as you get through the tense moment. That doesn't work in Tomb raider though, the grounds falling apart beneath you, there's a chopper shooting at you but you're just holding W and tapping space with a mildly bored and noting how conveniently that rock just fell, there’s no tension after the 30th time.   *Game Word* The ‘open world’ is hardly open, it’s filled with plenty of annoying rocks, shrubs and moderately high walls and rubble to act as lazy ways to box the player in. The second act is a pain to navigate as the maps not particularly effective, it’s not open it’s a series of tracks really and coupled with the terrible map and lazy walls figuring out how to get back to that collectable is a pain. Thats right i said collectables! the same damn collectables and mini tasks that you’ve seen in every AAA open world game in the last few years. It’s boring, uninspired and just a lazy way to pad out game time. These tasks include hunting and looting to support your open world standard crafting system with the usual lazy story locks on items making it completely redundant to even have.  One good addition however has been optional challenge tombs, there’s about 9 or 10 of these and they each feature a puzzle that needs to be solved to unlock some interesting perks at the end, these aren’t particularly taxing but they are enjoyable.  *Gameplay*  there have been improvements in some areas but very little in others, it’s mostly the same though.  The bulk of the game sees you climbing things and this is something the game has not advanced at all in. Things that you can interact with all have very obvious and ‘gamey’ visuals to them, there’s the really crumbled rock you can climb up and ledges and walls covered in bird droppings that you can grab onto or jump up and things with perfectly preserved rope around them. These stick out like a sore thumb and continuously remind you you're playing a game. Assassin's Creed has shown how you can have perfectly climbable buildings and trees and still have them feel almost natural so it’s not like this sort of climbing is a new idea. this is coupled with terrible keyboard climbing controls that lead to leaping of a cliff routinely. Climbing feels like you’re just holding down a button as you move through an incredibly artificial looking track.   Combat has improved though, Lara can now dodge effectively between cover instead of hobbling about into gunfire and getting stuck for a moment before dying, there’s a bit more enemy variety and ways to play this time round instead of popping up and down behind a rock. Enemies don’t die from one hit in stealth then turn straight Boromir levels of arrow tankiness the moment they notice you, there’s a bit more variety in the combat and it doesn’t play like a cover based shooter anymore which is wonderful.  Stealth gameplay is fun with multiple ways to clear out a group of bad guys, slowly pick them off with arrows or throw in some explosives and pick off the last guy quickly, there's plenty of room for play. Sadly there are maybe 10 or so encounters like this in the game, it’s fun to do but there is just nowhere near enough moments to play around with stealth, this is especially sad when there are so many perks that provide fun ways to play with stealth.  As for the rest of the gameplay, it’s a AAA open world game. There’s messages and tips popping up constantly that end up feeling patronising and annoying after a while, it constantly gives you experience and levels up things. I understand this stuff is to keep the casual kiddies entertained with a drip feed of arbitrary rewards but to someone who plays games regularly it’s maddening and you just wish you could turn it all off and enjoy the game.    Is it worth full price, no i got it to oggle at the graphics but still felt let down. Will it be worth it on sale? for $15 to look at the graphics it’s a good deal but other than that it’s still not worth it for gameplay.

When I was playing this game I felt optimistic, so I rated it thumbs up. However, now that I've finished it, that's changed. I took the time to type all of this out, even ways how I would like the game to improve. Please don't dislike this review without reading it just because you might like the game yourself. I gave a lot examples on how I would like the series to improve and maybe you'll like my recommendations as well, or maybe for an entirely new series.  Good:  - There's parts of the game that look really nice (and other parts that were low detailed). - I like the weapons, tools, grappling, abilities, etc. - I didn't run into too many bugs.  Bad:  - The story. It's not that interesting and it's very vague. It's about Lara Croft and others searching for ancient treasure that makes a person immortal. Lara said she wants it to study it and share it with the world...? The antagonist wants to become immortal. The lame part was that they don't know where it is or if it's even real. The back story was bland. - The dialog and acting was way too overly dramatic and revolved around revenge. - Not enough enemies types. There's 3 types of enemies: wild animals, male mercenaries, and the cursed men in armor (they're just reskined male mercenaries). So, it's repetitive. - Not enough music, I was getting tired of the same music playing over and over. I felt the same way with Bioshock Infinite. - Lara always has perfect skin right after a bloody battle to the death, then acts so chill about almost dying. She doesn't experience trauma apparently or at least for more than 2 seconds other than being sad about her dad dying when she was young. (not really a spoiler) - I didn't like how there's too many 'close call' instances throughout the game and also how everything she touches breaks instantly. - Lara's mouth doesn't move when she talks at times.  This game is like other treasure hunter stories where the antagonist and protagonist are simultaneously going after the same treasure. I think it would have been nice if it wasn't as linear and if the dialog wasn't overly dramatic. I would have liked more stuff similar to the concept art. This game focused too much on killing bad guys just like Tomb Raider (2013).   How to I would make improve the game: I think there should be an open world wilderness where you have to survive. Rarely, you come across abandoned buildings and towns that you can explore. You have to hunt for food, kill wild animals attacking you, and sleep (kind of like The Long Dark). There's also notes, books, and people that hints towards the locations of tombs. As you explore, you learn more stuff about the areas and it's secrets. You stumble across ancient ruins and temples that are much bigger than you expect. Each area has a different appearance, story, enemies, monsters, and music. So the game would be very diverse. It would also have a good story too that ties everything together. The characters would act to things realistically, for example in The Last of Us they had conversations that made the characters more alive.  Example of diversity between areas: 1. An ancient civilization at the bottom of an enormous, dark abyss with creepy mechanical monsters that crawls on the walls of buildings. 2. An ancient underwater civilization with evil mermaids and other weird sea stuff, also would be cool if there was bioluminescence. 3. An ancient civilization in an extinct volcano with slender man-like phantoms. Guns don't have any affect on them.. it's something else. 4. An ancient civilization in a valley covered with a invasive little flowers (like kudzu vines) which has fumes that makes Lara go completely crazy, seeing things that aren't there and having to fight that. There would be a bunch of these areas and each place would last around 3-6 hours of gameplay, maybe more. Pretty much, it would be an open world survival game mixed in with fantasy horror, exploring weird places, treasure hunting, and puzzle solving. I think that would be a lot more interesting and fun to play.

Its Graphics are probably the only thing that make this game worth buying. There are amazing veiws throughout the game. However, the game missed out on making the gameplay thrilling and the overall story interesting.  The major setback of the game is that it fails to meet the expectations of the players that have played the 2013 game. I found that there were hardly any puzzels in it, which is one of the major things that i missed in this game. What i missed in the gameplay was probably the 'survival' feeling. Furthermore, the story made Lara look a bit overpowered.  Close combat was also very rare. Oh and one more thing....why does Lara look so old!

Impressions gamut:  Early game: I know lara is doing a reboot, but she is such a whiny pansy and such a drama queen. Rolls eyes. Early combat: Ultra clunky, definitely no grace at all. Gears of war, cover fire style.  Mid game: They ramp up the complexity and the levels are linear to help guide the character, but non linear in that you need to look everywhere. Nice :) Mid Combat: fortunately there isn't much.  Late Game: exploration is unrewarding, but you get a cool tool thats fun to use in the levels! Late Combat: It still sucks, but i got used to it to some degree.  Overall: Character dialog and choices are very cinematic and non realistic. Lots of Eye rolling. So shooting hundreds of enemies is fine (not to mention the hundreds she brutally killed in the previous game), but she gets all emo and hesitant when a main baddie is around?  I'm just glad that the wussy lara story line is done now, so we can get back to the real lara! I honestly wouldn't tell my friends to buy this game... but its your choice, those are my impressions, i hope it helps you get an idea of what to expect!
